choices.text: Left lateral decubitus
Right lateral decubitus

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was originally admitted 5 days ago for peritonitis due to a perforated peptic ulcer, for which he underwent surgical repair. A large-bore, right internal jugular venous catheter was placed during the operation. Minutes after catheter removal, the patient develops acute-onset shortness of breath and cough. On examination, he appears in respiratory distress.  In addition to high-flow oxygen supplementation, the patient should be immediately placed in which of the following positions?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Left lateral decubitus

questions.text: Which of the following is the best investigation to calculate ejection fraction of the heart?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Cardiac MRI

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a mass at her right wrist. The patient first noticed swelling in her wrist a few months ago after spending a week knitting blankets for her family.  Medical conditions include hyperlipidemia and rheumatoid arthritis.  The mass is firm, mobile, and nontender to palpation, and it transilluminates on penlight examination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ganglion cyst

 

Ganglion cysts are the most common cause of a non-tender, firm, mobile swelling over the wrist, particularly following repeated hand movements or overuse. These cysts are fluid-filled, arising from tendon sheaths or joint capsules, and frequently transilluminate due to their clear gelatinous content. They are usually painless, may fluctuate in size, and are most often seen on the dorsal or volar aspect of the wrist, just as described in this patient with a history of knitting and risk factors including rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermoid-cyst: These are usually firm, non-transilluminant, slow-growing, and generally occur on the palmar surface of the hand or fingers rather than the wrist. They do not typically exhibit the clear, jelly-like content seen with ganglion cysts.

 

 

Option C. Lipoma: Lipomas are soft, pliable, subcutaneous tumors that do not transilluminate, and are much less likely to develop over the wrist than ganglion cysts.

 

 

Option D. Rheumatoid-nodule: These are firm, non-transilluminant, usually arise in patients with severe rheumatoid arthritis, and are often attached to periarticular structures or tendons, not mobile, and typically slightly tender. They rarely transilluminate and are less likely to be fluid-filled

choices.text: Used to detect tumor recurrence in brain tumors

questions.text: All are true about the image shown here except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Better contrast resolution than MRI

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the hospital due to erectile dysfunction.  A palpable plaque is present on the dorsal side of the penis approximately halfway between the glans and the pubis. The testes are normal with no scrotal erythema or skin ulceration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peyronie disease

 

  • Peyronie disease is characterized by fibrous plaque formation in the tunica albuginea of the penis, often leading to penile curvature, pain, and erectile dysfunction.
  • Lesions are typically palpable, dorsal, and midway along the shaft, as in this patient.
  • Genital warts are soft, verrucous lesions and rarely cause plaques or erectile dysfunction.
  • Penile cancer usually presents as ulcerative or nodular lesions, often with skin changes.
  • Systemic sclerosis can cause skin thickening and telangiectasia, but plaques localized to the penis are uncommon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genital warts: Incorrect. caused by HPV, present as soft papules or clusters, not firm plaques, and usually painless.

 

Option B. Penile cancer: Incorrect. typically presents as a non-healing ulcer or nodule, often with pain, bleeding, or skin changes.

 

Option D. Systemic sclerosis: Incorrect. causes diffuse skin thickening and microvascular changes, rarely isolated penile plaques.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to worsening right lower abdominal pain that radiates to the right groin area. Two weeks ago, he was treated for furunculosis of the right thigh. The patient has a history of type 1 diabetes mellites and takes insulin. Abdominal examination shows tenderness on deep palpation in the right lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. No masses are palpated. Bowel sounds are present. Extension of the right hip increases pain, and flexion decreases pain. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psoas abscess

 

Psoas abscess often arises from hematogenous spread or contiguous infection (eg, skin furunculosis, vertebral TB, Crohn’s).

 

  • Classic findings: pain in RLQ or flank, radiation to groin, positive psoas sign (pain with extension, relief with flexion).
  • Diabetes is a risk factor for deep-seated infections.

 

The image below shows Psoas abscess on left side.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute-appendicitis: Presents with RLQ pain, fever, anorexia, rebound tenderness; not typically relieved by hip flexion.

 

Option C. Small bowel-obstruction: Colicky pain, vomiting, distension, absent bowel movements; exam shows hyperactive bowel sounds initially.

 

Option D. Acute-pancreatitis: Epigastric pain radiating to back, nausea, vomiting; not localized to RLQ or affected by hip movement.

questions.text: 76-year-old man is admitted to the coronary care unit for cardiac catheterization which shows 70% left main coronary artery stenosis, 90% proximal left anterior descending artery stenosis. Antiplatelet agents are stopped, and the patient is continued on a heparin drip in preparation for coronary artery bypass surgery the next day. Five hours after the catheterization, his blood pressure is 75/60 mm Hg and pulse is 120/min and regular. He complains of some generalized weakness and back pain but denies chest pain, shortness of breath. On physical examination, he appears diaphoretic and clammy. Neck veins are flat.  The right groin arterial puncture site is mildly tender, without any swelling or bruits. He receives 1000 mL of normal saline with symptomatic improvement. His repeat ECG is unchanged from the initial ECG at presentation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the OPD for evaluation of new-onset foot pain. The pain is located at the heel and is most pronounced when she gets up from sitting after a long period of time. The patient is a soccer player. In addition, she enjoys running. Physical examination of the foot shows a moderately high arch with no discoloration or deformity. Direct pressure to the bottom of the heel elicits sharp pain, but mediolateral squeezing of the heel causes no discomfort. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of the patient's foot pain?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Inflammation of the plantar aponeurosis

choices.text: Medial collateral ligament injury

questions.text: 22-year-old soccer player comes to the emergency department for evaluation of a knee injury. During practice earlier that day, the patient felt her knee buckle when planting her right foot to kick the ball. Other players on the field recalled hearing an audible pop as she fell to the ground. On physical examination, the right knee is grossly swollen with limited range of motion due to pain. She is guarding on examination and has increased anterior translation of the tibia on the femur as compared to the contralateral side. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Anterior cruciate ligament injury

questions.text: 6-year-old boy is brought to the OPD for evaluation of back pain. The pain has been constant for the last 2 weeks and keeps the patient from playing with his friends. He wakes up several times nightly to void and has had episodes of incontinence as the leg pain prevents him from walking to the bathroom. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Langerhans cell histiocytosis 

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) in children can present with persistent back pain, restricted mobility, and vertebral lesions causing nocturnal symptoms and urinary dysfunction. Vertebral involvement may result in nerve root or spinal cord compression, explaining both the pain and episodes of incontinence described. LCH commonly affects flat bones, including the vertebrae, and produces lytic bone lesions; children present with bone pain, systemic complaints, and sometimes features of diabetes insipidus or neurological compromise. The constellation of long-standing back pain, sleep disturbance, and neurologic/urinary signs strongly favors LCH over more aggressive or syndromic entities in this pediatric age group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing-sarcoma: More commonly presents with fever, markedly elevated inflammatory markers, and aggressive soft tissue masses; pain is rapid in onset and usually associated with systemic signs. It is rare in children this young and classically affects diaphyseal bone.

 

 

Option C. Mazzabraud-syndrome: Features fibrous dysplasia and intramuscular myxomas, primarily presenting as slow-growing soft-tissue lumps and bony deformity rather than acute back pain or urinary symptoms; it is very rare in children.

 

Option D. Mccune-Albright.syndrome: Triad of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, café-au-lait spots, and endocrine abnormalities, most notably precocious puberty and hormonal excess. Such a syndrome rarely presents with isolated back pain and bladder dysfunction as primary symptoms

questions.text: All of the following could be the cause of the following X-ray finding except:

questions.text: Patient with history of tachyarrhythmias is on implantable cardioverter defibrillator. He develops shock. Best method to know the position and integrity of ICD is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plain radiograph

 

  • A plain chest radiograph (X-ray) is the best initial and most practical method to evaluate the position and integrity of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) and its leads. It can quickly show device location, lead placement, fractures, dislodgement, or malfunction.
  • Both posteroanterior (PA) and lateral chest X-rays are recommended for thorough assessment, providing two-plane views to confirm appropriate lead tip positions and device integrity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CECT: Not routinely used for device evaluation and involves contrast exposure.

 

Option B. MRI: Generally contraindicated or limited in patients with implanted cardiac devices due to risk of electromagnetic interference.

 

Option C. USG: Does not provide adequate imaging of ICD leads or device positioning.

choices.text: Nerve injury

questions.solution: Ans. B. Celiac disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to their primary care physician with a complaint of dysphagia. He reports that he experiences a sensation of food getting stuck in his throat when he eats. He also reports some mild chest discomfort with exertion. The patient has a history of Down syndrome and congenital heart disease. Barium swallow is shown here. Which imaging modality should be performed next?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Computed tomography angiography

choices.text: MRM in node negative patients
MRM in node positive patients
BCT in node negative patients
BCT in node positive patients

questions.text: In which of the given cases is this procedure usually performed?
questions.solution: Ans. C) BCT in node negative patients

questions.text: 55-year-old hypertensive male with acute chest pain, loss of consciousness, diaphoresis with unequal pulses in bilateral upper limbs. What is the best investigation in the emergency setting to reach the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A. TEE

choices.text: Antibiotics, fluid resuscitation, and admission to intensive care unit
Beta blockers, anticoagulation, and admission to intensive care unit

questions.text: 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to an episode of syncope while working in his garden. He has chest and neck pain that developed just prior to the syncopal episode. Temperature is 37.3° C (99.2 F), blood pressure is 144/92 mmHg on the right arm and 142/90 mm Hg on the left arm, and pulse is 109/min ECG shows sinus tachycardia, voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy, and no ST-segment or T-wave changes. Chest x-ray is shown. A bedside transthoracic echocardiogram shows a small pericardial effusion. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) CT angiography

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman with warfarin induced bleeding receives IV vitamin K, 4 U PRBCs and 4U FFP. 4h later, she begins to complain of shortness of breath. Vitals T - 39°C, RR 35/min, SpO2 84% on RA, and BP 88/52 mm Hg. Exam revealed B/L crackles and the patient was intubated for respiratory failure. CXR is as shown in the picture. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) TRALI

 

  • The patient developed acute respiratory distress (dyspnea, hypoxemia, tachypnea, hypotension) and bilateral crackles within 6 hours of receiving multiple blood product transfusions.
  • Chest X-ray shows bilateral pulmonary infiltrates.
  • TRALI is characterized by non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema occurring within 6 hours of transfusion, with fever, hypoxemia, and no evidence of circulatory overload or cardiac dysfunction.
  • Key features differentiating TRALI from TACO (Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload) include the presence of fever, hypotension (rather than hypertension), and absence of signs of fluid overload or elevated jugular venous pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaphylaxis: Presents with hypotension but is typically accompanied by urticaria, angioedema, and wheezing rather than isolated bilateral infiltrates.

 

Option B. TACO: Presents with signs of volume overload (hypertension, elevated JVP, S3) and usually no fever.

 

Option D. Aspiration: Would not be closely linked to recent transfusion and less likely to cause diffuse bilateral infiltrates so rapidly.

choices.text: Inserts into the lesser tubercle of the humerus
Primary function is external rotation
Arises from the subscapularis fossa
Supplied by a branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus

questions.text: All are true about the muscle whose function is tested in the below shown test except:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Primary function is external rotation

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with Raynaud’s phenomenon and tightening of skin of face and extremities presents with dyspnea and bilateral basal rales. What is the next best step?
questions.solution: Ans. A) HRCT chest

questions.text: 61-year-old man comes to the OPD due to chronic left knee pain. The pain is worse when he first gets out of bed in the morning and is associated with mild stiffness.  On examination, the left knee has a small effusion and mild pain over the medial and lateral joint lines. There is no clicking or locking of the knee, but crepitus is present with range of motion. The patient is able to bear weight without pain and the joint is stable to varus and valgus stress. X-ray of the knee is shown in the image below: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's knee pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quadriceps strengthening exercises

 

  • The patient is a 61-year-old man with chronic knee pain, stiffness, crepitus, and small effusion, consistent with osteoarthritis.
  • X-ray shows joint space narrowing and osteophytes, typical of OA.
  • Initial management of mild-to-moderate OA includes non-pharmacologic measures: quadriceps strengthening exercises, weight loss, and activity modification.
  • NSAIDs or intra-articular corticosteroid injections are considered when conservative therapy fails.
  • Knee replacement is reserved for severe, disabling OA not relieved by other measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate: Used in rheumatoid arthritis, not OA.

 

Option B. Corticosteroid injection of the knee: Provides short-term relief in moderate to severe OA with significant symptoms, not the first-line step.

 

Option C. Knee replacement surgery: Reserved for advanced OA with severe pain and functional limitation.

choices.text: Better than teletherapy for Large & Bulky tumor
Deliver higher dose of radiation to tumor

questions.text: All of the following is true about brachytherapy except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Better than teletherapy for Large & Bulky tumor

questions.text: 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. Blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg and pulse is 102/min. Abdominal palpation shows fullness and tenderness in the suprapubic region. There is no blood at the urethral meatus, and digital rectal examination reveals a normal prostate. Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma reveals no intraperitoneal free fluid. Pelvic x-ray reveals fracture of the left pubic ramus. A Foley catheter is placed without resistance with immediate return of bloody urine. Emergency CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is performed. Which of the following injuries is most likely to be seen on CT scan in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Anterior bladder wall rupture

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of backache. On examination, her eyes and pinna revealed blackish discoloration. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Alkaptonuria

choices.text: Insert iv cannula and start iv fluids
Left needle thoracostomy followed by ICD

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with sudden onset breathlessness and a sharp pain in his chest after a road traffic accident. His BP is 85/69mm Hg and HR is 110bpm. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the next step for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Right Needle thoracostomy

choices.text: Inferior mesenteric artery
Inferior vena cava

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman comes to the office due to fever, dysuria, and abdominal pain. The patient has had several urinary tract infections since her teens but has no other medical concerns. Physical examination shows mild suprapubic discomfort. Urinalysis demonstrates pyuria and many bacteria. CT scan of the abdomen is shown in the image below:

 

 

Which of the following structures has most likely limited the proper ascent of the anomalous organ seen on CT scan?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Inferior mesenteric artery

questions.text: 26-year-old man with a history of seizure disorder and medication nonadherence is hospitalized after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. A witness reports that the patient lost consciousness and fell to his right side; the seizure lasted about 2 minutes. Evaluation in the emergency department reveals a low serum level of his prescribed antiepileptic drug. levetiracetam, and a displaced right femur fracture. Levetiracetam is restarted and the patient undergoes intramedullary nailing of the fracture with no intraoperative complications. The next day the patient is noted to be confused. Temperature is 37.2 °C (99 °F), blood pressure is 142/86 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 28/min. Oxygen saturation is 90% while breathing room air. On physical examination, the patient is disoriented but has no focal weakness or sensory loss. There are no skin rashes or hematoma at the surgical site. CT pulmonary angiography shows bilateral scattered ground-glass opacities but no flling defects within the pulmonary vasculature. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fat embolism

 

  • This patient developed confusion + tachypnea + hypoxemia within 24–72 hours after a long bone fracture (femur).
  • CT chest shows bilateral ground-glass opacities without embolic filling defects, which is classic for fat embolism syndrome (FES) rather than pulmonary embolism.
  • The triad of respiratory distress, neurological symptoms, and petechial rash defines FES (rash may appear later or be absent).
  • Risk is highest after intramedullary nailing of long bones due to marrow fat release into circulation.

 

Gerd’s Criteria of Fat Embolism

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient is being evaluated for a suspected brain tumor. A biopsy is obtained whose image has been shown below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis based upon the biopsy findings?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Oligodendroglioma

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented to the clinic with a persistent cough, fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats. X-ray of the patient is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection

questions.text:
59-year-old woman comes to the office for routine visit. She reports no symptoms. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender mass in the right upper quadrant. The remainder of the examination is within normal limits. Abdominal CT scan is shown in the image below.

 

 

What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Porcelain GB

questions.text: A woman presented to the clinic with heavy, painful menses that have worsened over the past year. On pelvic examination the uterus is enlarged and tender. MRI scan of the patient’s abdomen revealed a finding similar to the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: 42-year-old woman reports bloating with mild, diffuse abdominal discomfort 4 days after undergoing an elective cholecystectomy. She has not passed gas since the surgery. Perioperatively, she received antibiotics, morphine for pain, and metoclopramide for nausea.  Physical examination shows a distended, tympanic abdomen with decreased bowel sounds. There is mild, diffuse tenderness but no rebound or guarding. Which of the following is most likely contributing to this patient's current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Morphine

Plain film x-ray of the right shoulder is shown below.  If left untreated, which of the following is the most likely complication of this patient's injury?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Shoulder abduction weakness

questions.text: 59-year-old man comes to the office for a postoperative follow-up. He underwent a partial (distal) gastrectomy for a perforated peptic ulcer 3 weeks ago. For the last 10 days, he has had intermittent abdominal cramps and diarrhea. Symptoms begin 25-30 minutes after eating and are associated with nausea, weakness, palpitations, light-headedness, and diaphoresis. The patient has no symptoms overnight, and there is no associated fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Dumping syndrome

questions.solution: Ans. A) Gibson incision

choices.text: Leydig cell tumor

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the office due to a progressive increase in breast size over the past 6 months.  Genitourinary examination reveals a 1-cm nodule in the right testis. The examination is otherwise normal. Laboratory results are as follows

 

LH: 3 U/L (normal 6-23 U/L)

FSH: 2 U/L (normal 4-25 U/L)

Testosterone: 270 ng/dL (normal: 300-1,000 ng/dL)

Estradiol: 115 pg/mL (normal: 20-60 pg/mL)

B-hCG: undetectable

Alpha-fetoprotein: undetectable

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Leydig cell tumor
